raw_text:
Chepkemei joins Edinburgh line-up
 
 Susan Chepkemei has decided she is fit enough to run in next month's Great Edinburgh International Cross Country.
 
 The Kenyan was initially unsure if she would have recovered from her gruelling tussle with Paula Radcliffe in the New York Marathon in time to compete. But she has declared herself up to the task and joins a field headed by World cross country champion Benita Johnson. Race director Matthew Turnbull said: "Susan will add even more strength in depth to the world-class line up." Chepkemei, who won the six kilometre event three years ago when it was staged in Newcastle, endured an epic battle with Radcliffe in the Big Apple until the Briton outsprinted her in the final 400m. Tirunesh Dibaba of Ethiopia will defend the title she won last year in Tyneside - before the race was moved north of the border. Recently-crowned European cross country champion Briton Hayley Yelling also competes in Edinburgh on 15 January, as does in-form Scot Kathy Butler.
llama3.2:1b: Susan Chepkemei joins the Great Edinburgh International Cross Country field, including World champion Benita Johnson and Ethiopian titleholder Tirunesh Dibaba, after initially declaring herself unfit due to a past marathon performance issue.
llama3.2:3b: Susan Chepkemei has decided to run in next month's Great Edinburgh International Cross Country despite initially being unsure if she had recovered from her New York Marathon battle with Paula Radcliffe. She joins a strong field led by Benita Johnson and defends the six kilometre event title won three years ago, while Tirunesh Dibaba defends her overall title and Hayley Yelling and Kathy Butler also compete.
gemma2:2b: Susan Chepkemei is running in the Great Edinburgh International Cross Country after recovering from her marathon competition with Paula Radcliffe. She joins a strong field that includes Benita Johnson, Tirunesh Dibaba, and Hayley Yelling.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Susan Chepkemei has joined the Edinburgh line-up for next month's Great Edinburgh International Cross Country Marathon after successfully completing her six kilometre race against Paula Radcliffe at New York City. She will compete with World cross country champion Benita Johnson and have added depth to the world-class field of runners heading into the event in Edinburgh on 15 January.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Kenyan runner Susan Chepkemei is confirmed to participate in the Great Edinburgh International Cross Country alongside reigning world and European champions for her second appearance at the event, taking place just before a move north of Scotland. The field also includes Ethiopia's Tirunesh Dibaba, defending champion from two years ago, who was displaced due to a venue change; UK's Hayley Yelling is making her debut after becoming an international competitor in 2019, and Scottish athlete Kathy Butler will participate as well.
qwen2.5:3b: Susan Chepkemei has decided to compete in next month's Great Edinburgh International Cross Country despite initial doubts due to her race against Paula Radcliffe in the New York Marathon. She joins a strong field led by World cross country champion Benita Johnson. Chepkemei won six kilometers in Newcastle three years ago and will add strength to the world-class lineup. Other notable competitors include European cross country champion Hayley Yelling and Scot Kathy Butler.

<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Susan Chepkemei joining the Edinburgh line-up for a marathon. Let me read through it carefully.

First, the main points are: Susan Chepkemei is joining the race after beating Paula Radcliffe in New York. She won a 6 km event three years ago, so she's fit enough to compete. The race director says she'll add strength to the team led by Benita Johnson, who's already world-class.

Then, other runners are coming up: Tirunesh Dibaba from Ethiopia, Hayley Yelling from the UK, and Kathy Butler from Scotland. They're all in on January 15th, so it's about the day of the race.

I should focus on Susan joining, her previous win, who's leading, and the rest of the runners. I'll keep it concise without adding anything else.
</think>

Susan Chepkemei joins the Edinburgh International Cross Country field after defeating Paula Radcliffe in the New York Marathon to compete at a world-class strength-packed team led by Benita Johnson. Tirunesh Dibaba from Ethiopia, Hayley Yelling, and Scot Kathy Butler are also participating on January 15th.
tinyllama:1.1b: Chepkemei is set to run at Great Edinburgh International Cross Country. The Kenyan was initially unsure if she would have recovered from her grueling tussle with Paula Radcliffe in New York Marathon, but she has declared herself up to the task and has been confirmed for a star-studded lineup that includes World cross country champion Benita Johnson. Race director Matthew Turnbull said Chepkemei's "extraordinary performance" in Boston last year would give her an advantage at the Scottish capital's iconic event, which takes place on 15 January. Tirunesh Diaba and Kathy Butler will also compete as part of a top-class lineup that also includes recent European cross country champion Hayley Yelling.

She joins a strong field led by World cross country champion Benita Johnson. Race director Matthew Turnbull praised her inclusion, adding depth to the competition. Chepkemei, a former winner of the six-kilometre event, will compete alongside defending champion Tirunesh Dibaba, European champion Hayley Yelling, and Scottish runner Kathy Butler on 15 January.
reference: Susan Chepkemei has decided she is fit enough to run in next month's Great Edinburgh International Cross Country.Recently-crowned European cross country champion Briton Hayley Yelling also competes in Edinburgh on 15 January, as does in-form Scot Kathy Butler.Chepkemei, who won the six kilometre event three years ago when it was staged in Newcastle, endured an epic battle with Radcliffe in the Big Apple until the Briton outsprinted her in the final 400m.
